message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: The impact of feedbacks on evolutionary game dynamics in structured populations
Paper Abstract: In this paper, we investigate how the structure of a lattice network influences the outcomes of an evolutionary game that includes environmental feedback. Specifically, we study how the number of neighbors each individual has affects population strategies under three different update rules: birth–death, death–birth, and imitation. Our results show both similarities and differences among these update rules. The similarity is that individuals generally prefer defection when the environment is rich but tend to cooperate more often when the environment is poor. The key difference arises between the birth–death and imitation update rules compared to the death–birth rule. Under the birth–death and imitation rules, the number of neighbors affects cooperation levels only when the system reaches a boundary equilibrium, whereas under the death–birth rule, the number of neighbors does not have this effect. Additionally, compared to those populations without structured networks, we find that lattice network structures help to maintain cooperation, even when individuals face the prisoner’s dilemma. This suggests that lattice structures help individuals resist the temptation to defect, promoting social harmony and sustainable development.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Web search results for query: "Birth-death process"

Links: [{"title":"Birth–death process","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Birth–death_process"},{"title":"Quasi-birth–death process","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quasi-birth–death_process"},{"title":"Moran process - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Moran_process"},{"title":"Template:Death date and age - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Template:Death-date_and_age"}]

## Birth-Death Process

A birth-death process is a special case of continuous-time Markov process where the state transitions are of only two types: "births," which increase the state variable by one and "deaths," which decrease the state by one.(no content)It was introduced by William Feller.

### Applications

Birth–death processes have applications in demography, queueing theory, performance engineering, epidemiology, biology and other areas, and may be used to study the evolution of bacteria, the number of people with a disease within a population, or the number of customers in line at the supermarket.

### How It Works

When a birth occurs, the process goes from state n to n + 1. When a death occurs, the process goes from state n to state n − 1.

### Related Processes

The quasi-birth–death process describes a generalization of the birth–death process. As with the birth-death process it moves up and down between levels one at a time, but the time between these transitions can have a more complicated distribution.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about the Prisoner's Dilemma:

## The Concept

The prisoner's dilemma is a game theory thought experiment involving two rational agents, each of whom can either cooperate for mutual benefit or betray their partner ("defect") for individual gain.(no content)The dilemma arises from the fact that while defecting is rational for each agent, cooperation yields a higher payoff for each.

## Real-World Application

In casual usage, the label "prisoner's dilemma" is applied to any situation in which two entities can gain important benefits by cooperating or suffer by failing to do so, but find it difficult or expensive to coordinate their choices.

## History

The puzzle was designed by Merrill Flood and Melvin Dresher in 1950 during their work at the RAND Corporation, and they invited economist Armen Alchian and mathematician John Williams to play a hundred rounds of the game.(no content)Albert W. Tucker later named the game the "prisoner's dilemma" by framing the rewards in terms of prison sentences.

## Importance in Game Theory

The iterated prisoner's dilemma is fundamental to some theories of human cooperation and trust, and cooperative behavior in populations can be modeled by a multi-player iterated version of the game.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Evolutionary game theory"

Links: [{"title":"Evolutionary game theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolutionary_game_theory"},{"title":"Category:Evolutionary game theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Evolutionary_game_theory"},{"title":"Talk:Evolutionary game theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Evolutionary_game_theory"},{"title":"Evolutionarily stable strategy - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolutionarily_stable_strategy"},{"title":"Evolution and the Theory of Games - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolution_and_the_Theory_of_Games"},{"title":"Evolutionary economics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolutionary_economics"},{"title":"Evolutionary graph theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolutionary_graph_theory"},{"title":"Game theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Game_theory"},{"title":"Category:Evolutionary theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Evolutionary_theory"}]

Here are the search results for "Evolutionary game theory":

## Overview

Evolutionary game theory (EGT) is the application of game theory to evolving populations in biology. It defines a framework of contests, strategies, and analytics into which Darwinian competition can be modelled.

## Origins

EGT originated in 1973 with John Maynard Smith and George R. Price's formalisation of contests, analysed as strategies, and the mathematical criteria that can be used to predict the results of competing strategies.

## Key Differences from Classical Game Theory

Evolutionary game theory differs from classical game theory in focusing more on the dynamics of strategy change. This is influenced by the frequency of the competing strategies in the population. Additionally, an evolutionary version of game theory does not require players to act rationally—only that they have a strategy. The results of a game show how good that strategy was, just as evolution tests alternative strategies for the ability to survive and reproduce.

## Key Concepts

In biology, strategies are genetically inherited traits that control an individual's action, analogous with computer programs. The success of a strategy is determined by how good the strategy is in the presence of competing strategies (including itself), and of the frequency with which those strategies are used.

A central concept is the evolutionarily stable strategy (ESS), which is a strategy (or set of strategies) that is impermeable when adopted by a population in adaptation to a specific environment.

## Applications and Interdisciplinary Interest

Evolutionary game theory has helped to explain the basis of altruistic behaviours in Darwinian evolution. It has in turn become of interest to economists, sociologists, anthropologists, and philosophers.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Additionally, an evolutionary version of game theory does not require players to act rationally—only that they have a strategy. The results of a game show how good that strategy was, just as evolution tests alternative strategies for the ability to survive and reproduce.

## Key Concepts

In biology, strategies are genetically inherited traits that control an individual's action, analogous with computer programs. The success of a strategy is determined by how good the strategy is in the presence of competing strategies (including itself), and of the frequency with which those strategies are used.

A central concept is the evolutionarily stable strategy (ESS), which is a strategy (or set of strategies) that is impermeable when adopted by a population in adaptation to a specific environment.

## Applications and Interdisciplinary Interest

Evolutionary game theory has helped to explain the basis of altruistic behaviours in Darwinian evolution. It has in turn become of interest to economists, sociologists, anthropologists, and philosophers.

Here are the key findings about cooperation and defection in game theory:

## The Prisoner's Dilemma

The prisoner's dilemma is a game theory thought experiment involving two rational agents, each of whom can either cooperate for mutual benefit or betray their partner ("defect") for individual gain.(no content)The dilemma arises from the fact that while defecting is rational for each agent, cooperation yields a higher payoff for each.

## Iterated Games and Cooperation

Cooperation can emerge in repeated interactions, even in situations where it is not rational in a one-off interaction.(no content)The iterated prisoner's dilemma is fundamental to some theories of human cooperation and trust. Assuming that the game effectively models transactions between two people that require trust, cooperative behavior in populations can be modeled by a multi-player iterated version of the game.

## Popular Strategies

**Tit-for-Tat:** An agent using this strategy will first cooperate, then subsequently replicate an opponent's previous action. If the opponent previously was cooperative, the agent is cooperative. If not, the agent is not.

**Grim Trigger:** A player using grim trigger will cooperate, but as soon as the opponent defects, the player using grim trigger will defect for the remainder of the iterated game.

## Real-World Applications

Many instances of human interaction and natural processes have payoff matrices like the prisoner's dilemma's. It is therefore of interest to the social sciences, such as economics, politics, and sociology, as well as to the biological sciences, such as ethology and evolutionary biology.

Links: [{"title":"Lattice network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lattice_network"},{"title":"Lattice delay network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lattice_delay_network"},{"title":"Lattice graph - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lattice_graph"},{"title":"Lattice and bridged-T equalizers - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lattice_and_bridged-T_equalizers"},{"title":"Watts–Strogatz model","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Watts–Strogatz_model"},{"title":"Evolution of a random network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolution_of_a_random_network"},{"title":"Equivalent impedance transforms - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Equivalent_impedance_transforms"},{"title":"Hirschlanden transmitter - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hirschlanden_transmitter"},{"title":"Percolation threshold - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Percolation_threshold"},{"title":"Bartlett's bisection theorem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bartlett's_bisection_theorem"}]

Based on the web search results, here's information about lattice networks:

## Electrical Lattice Networks

A symmetrical lattice is a two-port electrical wave filter in which diagonally-crossed shunt elements are present – a configuration which sets it apart from ladder networks.

### Structure and Components

The filter properties include a duplication of components in the lattice network as the "series impedances" (instances of Za) and "shunt impedances" (instances of Zb) both occur twice, an arrangement that offers increased flexibility to the circuit designer with a variety of responses achievable.

### Applications and Characteristics

It is possible for the lattice network to have the characteristics of: a delay network, an amplitude or phase correcting network, a dispersive network or as a linear phase filter, according to the choice of components for the lattice elements.(no content)Lattice delay networks are an important subgroup of lattice networks. They are all-pass filters, so they have a flat amplitude response, but a phase response which varies linearly (or almost linearly) with frequency.

### Key Advantages

It is possible with this circuit to have the characteristic impedance specified independently of its transmission properties, a feature not available to ladder filter structures. In addition, it is possible to design the circuit to be a constant-resistance network for a range of circuit characteristics.(no content)Lattice and bridged-T equalizers are circuits which are used to correct for the amplitude and/or phase errors of a network or transmission line. Usually, the aim is to achieve an overall system performance with a flat amplitude response and constant delay over a prescribed frequency range.

I've completed the web search for "Network topology graph structure." Here's a summary of the key findings:

## Network Topology and Graph Structure

Network topology is the topological structure of a network, depicted physically or logically, and is an application of graph theory wherein communicating devices are modeled as nodes and the connections between the devices are modeled as links or lines between the nodes.

### Common Network Topologies

The search results identify several key network topology types:

- **Fully Connected Networks**: In a fully connected network, all nodes are interconnected (in graph theory this is called a complete graph).

- **Tree Topology**: A tree topology (hierarchical topology) can be viewed as a collection of star networks arranged in a hierarchy.

- **Daisy Chain Topology**: Daisy chain topology is a way of connecting network nodes in a linear or ring structure and is used to transmit messages from one node to the next until they reach the destination node.

- **Mesh Topology**: In a partially connected mesh topology, there are at least two nodes with two or more paths between them to provide redundant paths in case the link providing one of the paths fails.

### Physical vs. Logical Topology

Logical topology is the way that the signals act on the network media, or the way that the data passes through the network from one device to the next without regard to the physical interconnection of the devices, and a network's logical topology is not necessarily the same as its physical topology.

The search results also cover specialized network types like scale-free networks, small-world networks, and hierarchical network models, which exhibit specific structural properties beyond simple topology.

I've completed the web search for "Network topology graph structure." Here's a summary of the key findings:

## Network Topology and Graph Structure

Network topology is the topological structure of a network, depicted physically or logically, and is an application of graph theory wherein communicating devices are modeled as nodes and the connections between the devices are modeled as links or lines between the nodes.

### Common Network Topologies

The search results identify several key network topology types:

- **Fully Connected Networks**: In a fully connected network, all nodes are interconnected (in graph theory this is called a complete graph).

- **Tree Topology**: A tree topology (hierarchical topology) can be viewed as a collection of star networks arranged in a hierarchy.

- **Daisy Chain Topology**: Daisy chain topology is a way of connecting network nodes in a linear or ring structure and is used to transmit messages from one node to the next until they reach the destination node.

- **Mesh Topology**: In a partially connected mesh topology, there are at least two nodes with two or more paths between them to provide redundant paths in case the link providing one of the paths fails.

### Physical vs. Logical Topology

Logical topology is the way that the signals act on the network media, or the way that the data passes through the network from one device to the next without regard to the physical interconnection of the devices, and a network's logical topology is not necessarily the same as its physical topology.

The search results also cover specialized network types like scale-free networks, small-world networks, and hierarchical network models, which exhibit specific structural properties beyond simple topology.

A. P. Moran - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/P._A._P._Moran"},{"title":"Structuralism (biology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Structuralism_(biology)"},{"title":"Eco-evolutionary dynamics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eco-evolutionary_dynamics"},{"title":"Fleming–Viot process - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fleming–Viot_process"},{"title":"Evolutionary dynamics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolutionary_dynamics"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of the Moran process and its role in evolutionary dynamics:

## Overview

A Moran process or Moran model is a simple stochastic process used in biology to describe finite populations.(no content)The process is named after Patrick Moran, who first proposed the model in 1958.

## Applications in Evolutionary Biology

It can be used to model variety-increasing processes such as mutation as well as variety-reducing effects such as genetic drift and natural selection.(no content)The process can describe the probabilistic dynamics in a finite population of constant size N in which two alleles A and B are competing for dominance. In each time step a random individual is chosen for reproduction and a random individual is chosen for death; thus ensuring that the population size remains constant.

## Key Features

To model selection, one type has to have a higher fitness and is thus more likely to be chosen for reproduction.(no content)Neutral drift is the idea that a neutral mutation can spread throughout a population, so that eventually the original allele is lost. A neutral mutation does not bring any fitness advantage or disadvantage to its bearer. The simple case of the Moran process can describe this phenomenon.

## Related Research Areas

Moran processes are related to the Wright–Fisher process, and Fleming–Viot processes arise as infinite population limits of suitably rescaled variants of Moran processes. Additionally, a graph has the same fixation probability as the corresponding Moran process if and only if it is isothermal, where the sum of all weights that lead into a vertex is the same for all vertices.

I've found comprehensive information about birth-death processes. Here's what I found:

## Birth-Death Process Overview

A birth-death process is a special case of continuous-time Markov process where the state transitions are of only two types: "births", which increase the state variable by one and "deaths", which decrease the state by one.(no content)It was introduced by William Feller.

## How It Works

When a birth occurs, the process goes from state n to n + 1. When a death occurs, the process goes from state n to state n − 1.

## Applications

Birth-death processes have many applications in demography, queueing theory, performance engineering, epidemiology, biology and other areas. They may be used, for example, to study the evolution of bacteria, the number of people with a disease within a population, or the number of customers in line at the supermarket.

## Real-World Context

The birth-death process is a simple stochastic model that describes how populations fluctuate over time due to random births and deaths. These models are particularly important when dealing with small populations, where random events can have large impacts, such as in the case of endangered species or small microbial populations.

## Mathematical Properties

If a birth-and-death process is ergodic, then there exist steady-state probabilities. Additionally, conditions for recurrence and transience were established by Samuel Karlin and James McGregor.

I've found comprehensive information about birth-death processes. Here's what I found:

## Birth-Death Process Overview

A birth-death process is a special case of continuous-time Markov process where the state transitions are of only two types: "births", which increase the state variable by one and "deaths", which decrease the state by one.(no content)It was introduced by William Feller.

## How It Works

When a birth occurs, the process goes from state n to n + 1. When a death occurs, the process goes from state n to state n − 1.

## Applications

Birth-death processes have many applications in demography, queueing theory, performance engineering, epidemiology, biology and other areas. They may be used, for example, to study the evolution of bacteria, the number of people with a disease within a population, or the number of customers in line at the supermarket.

## Real-World Context

The birth-death process is a simple stochastic model that describes how populations fluctuate over time due to random births and deaths. These models are particularly important when dealing with small populations, where random events can have large impacts, such as in the case of endangered species or small microbial populations.

## Mathematical Properties

If a birth-and-death process is ergodic, then there exist steady-state probabilities. Additionally, conditions for recurrence and transience were established by Samuel Karlin and James McGregor.
